narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Workshopped 2 of my own short stories and gave written and oral feedback to my peers.
I learned to write and rewrite short stories with feedback from my professor and peers.

This class was revelatory, and Caz is a fantastic mentor. I learned how to structure a short story to create inertia, focus, and clarity. Learned how to edit and identify the most important characters or movements, and how to remove the rest. My writing improved immensely and I learned that less is often more. He helped us drill deeper into our characters to make stories that felt organic, yet focused. Reading everyones pieces and diving into them really taught me how to identify what makes a good story, and borrow those strategies in my own work.

I developed the skill of how to craft a solid short story by focusing on character. By focusing on character, all of the other elements of a good short story like plot, setting, and dialogue will more easily fall into place. I also learned what works in a story, how to make aspects of a story more clear, and also how much background to include.
I was able to work on my writing in a more concentrated way, because we had to write 2 short stories and spend time really crafting our work.
I learned how to read and write short stories.
Writing long fictional narratives, building strong characters, writing and providing constructive feedback for other writers

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Although it was over Zoom, I really looked forward to seeing everyone's faces and talking about stories! Hearing other people's feedback helped me formulate my own. I also loved reading everyone's original fiction over the course of the semester. It tended towards realistic fiction, which I think best suited the professor's needs. Even still, when we got something different in genre it was really exciting.

The best part of this course is the strength of the writers present. The caliber of writing and feedback really pushes you to improve your own writing and read thoughtfully, but in a collaborative and non-competitive way. Caz will also take time to talk about your stories or your writing career with you midway through the semester, and we got to meet with a literary agent at the end which was cool.

Strengths- Caz is a fantastic professor and I learned so much from him! He's generous with his time and always available via email or office hours. I really appreciated every minute I spent talking to him; he can quickly identify the problems with a piece, and really helped me distill what I was trying to do in the work. He's a harsh critic  but I loved it. That's why we're here, and the blunt feedback worked wonders. (in my opinion.) I loved the workshop element of class, it was a joy to read these varied, diverse pieces, and see how differently everyone wrote. I definitely grew close to a few folks in the class and it was great to have that. The Q&A with a literary agent at the end was also really helpful and grounded the class in the realities of the profession. 
Weaknesses- The workshop also depends a lot upon the commitment of the students in it, so the live critique really depends on whether your peers are staying focused... which seems hard over zoom. Also a few peers didn't always send in their "workshop letters" to you after Caz stopped requiring them to be sent to him... so that led to a kind of asymmetrical experience where you might spend a lot of time trying to critique others' work but not getting the same support in return.  But this might be because there's less of a "community" via zoom.

I honestly think there are really just strengths. The class is very enjoyable because you really focus on other people's stories along with your own and learn a lot through the large amount of reading and commenting you do.
The class format is really helpful because it is a workshop - I was able to get/give really detailed feedback for my classmates and from the professor.

Strengths: Peers and Caz provide insightful feedback. The workshop structure is ideal.
Weaknesses: None!

Because students only write two stories in this course, there was less opportunity to improve my writing or explore many ideas. It would have been nice to write more stories. After workshops, each student sends a 1-page letter of feedback about your story. However, Professor Phillips does not send feedback until after you have submitted your final draft. I found this to be counter-intuitive, as I only had his verbal in-class comments to go off of. In previous creative writing classes I've taken, the professor will send a 1 or 2 page letter of feedback after a workshop to take into consideration for the final draft. This allowed me to learn and grow as a writer. I feel that I did not grow as a writer in this class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how people could add notes and follow-ups in the chat without disturbing the oral discussion. Other than that, I think the virtual seminar happened to the best it could.
This course had a pretty standard zoom meeting set up. It could only have been improved by meeting in person, which wasn't possible.

Calling on each student during the workshops made sense in theory, but sometimes I could tell students were zoning out or going back to work on classwork for other classes once Caz had called on them and they'd "said" their bit... That ran a little counter to the "discussion" aspect that makes seminars so engaging. This wasn't at all Caz's fault. I guess it's just hard for some students to stay focused when you have less of an in-person group dynamic and feeling of responsibility to others.. also it's a pandemic-specific situation
I think all succeeded! I didn't actually feel that I was missing anything I would normally have without COVID besides meeting up in celebration at the end of the semester.
I think this course format translates pretty well into an online setting, just because we were still able to meet and discuss our work in real time.
I believe we made the best of a virtual semester.
The virtual seminar format of this class was handled as well as it could have been.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This class was my favorite of the semester.  Reading everyone's stories every week was something I really looked forward to and I grew to really respect my peers. Even though it was over Zoom, I was always excited to see people's faces and hear what they liked about the story. Overall, I think the class this semester was chosen well, and created a really welcoming and helpful atmosphere.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who wants to take their prose writing to the next level. It's the only course at Yale where I ever wished there was more work!

Yes! This course makes you a better writer and you come out with a grounded, more deliberate sense of how to write, and how to communicate a story that's in your head. Going through the motions of writing, rewriting, and editing is critical, and Caz's frank feedback and expertise was invaluable.
Yes absolutely, if you love to write you'll definitely enjoy this course. All your classmates are so talented so their stories are a joy to read, and you get great feedback on your own work.
Yes, especially if they are looking to improve their writing skills in a class that devotes time to purely writing. I would say this for majors and non-majors.
Yes! Caz is a great professor and you learn a lot from your peers.

No, but perhaps I would have enjoyed it more if I had not taken it during the pandemic. I don't think that Professor Phillips' teaching style jived well with how I learn best, but that is because each individual is different.
